captions.text:
Russell:
When you are studying any matter
Or considering any philosophy,
Ask yourself only: what are the facts,
And what is the truth that the facts bear out

Sagan:
Science is more than a body of knowledge;
It's a way of thinking
A way of skeptically interrogating the universe.
If we are not able to ask skeptical questions
To be skeptical of those in authority
Then we're up for grabs

Shermer:
In all of science we're looking for a balance
between data and theory

Harris:
You don't have to delude yourself
With Iron age fairy tales

Porco:
The same spiritual fulfillment
That people find in religion
Can be found in science
By coming to know, if you will, the mind of God

Krauss:
The real world, as it actually is,
Is not evil, it's remarkable
And the way to understand the physical world
is to use science

Dawkins:
There is a new wave of reason
Sweeping across America, Britain, Europe, Australia
South America, the Middle East and Africa
There is a new wave of reason
Where superstition had a firm hold

Plait:
Teach a man to reason
And he'll think for a lifetime

Sagan:
Cosmology brings us face to face with the deepest mysteries
With questions that were once treated only
in religion and myth
The desire to be connected with the cosmos
Reflects a profound reality
But we are connected; not in the trivial ways
That Astrology promises, but in the deepest ways

Feynman:
I can't believe the special stories that have been made up
About our relationship to the universe at large
Look at what's out there; it isn't in proportion

Sagan:
Science is more than a body of knowledge
It's a way of thinking
A way of skeptically interrogating the universe

Dawkins:
There is a new wave of reason
Sweeping across America, Britain, Europe, Australia
South America, the Middle East and Africa
There is a new wave of reason
Where superstition had a firm hold

Plait:
Teach a man to reason
And he'll think for a lifetime

Russell:
Never let yourself be diverted
By what you wish to believe
But look only and surely
At what are the facts

Randi:
Enjoy the fantasy, the fun, the stories
But make sure that there's a clear sharp line
Drawn on the floor
To do otherwise is to embrace madness

Dawkins:
There is a new wave of reason
Sweeping across America, Britain, Europe, Australia
South America, the Middle East and Africa
There is a new wave of reason
Where superstition had a firm hold

Plait:
Teach a man to reason
And he'll think for a lifetime

comments.text:
+Rex Irkalla I dont believe you live in Portugal... Because you would NEVER 
had said "It's Britain and the rest of Europe".

Or well, you could also have an inferiority complex. But i don't think you 
live in Europe.

Anyways. In English you have the word "The" as only possibility... In 
German it can be Der, Die, Das... that's 3 times more, so 3 times more 
complex.

In English you have the word "Walk" and it stays the same in every form. I 
walk, You walk, We walk, they walk...

In German and In Dutch too, that word "walk" changes in EVERY instance. ich 
laufe
du läufst
er/sie/es läuft
wir laufen
ihr lauft
sie/Sie laufen

In English you just say "mine".. In German, it depends on the sentence... 
It can be mein, meine, meiner, meinem, meinen and meines...

And you even THINK that English is not easier? This is not a point of 
discussion. English is SIMPLY easier. THAT is a great reason for Europe to 
take English as a trade language. And IT is the reason why it was voted to 
be the language in the US. Because they were also thinking about making 
Dutch the language in the US, but they went for English in the end. Yes,, 
there was a vote for that... It was not because of power or rule.

And now you translate your book into English to sell it to the west... 
Because we agreed upon that language... If you want to sell your book in 
Russia, you have to translate it to Russian cause your English version is 
not gonna sell well.. Same goes for China and India...

And if you are so knowledgeable about the Dutch and the Germans, then you 
would know they have practically the same culture as the Britsh. Some minor 
differences, but in essence, they are the same. And the Brits have NEVER 
occupied the Netherlands OR Germany. There is no conquest involved, we have 
been trading and talking for centuries and we "grew up" together. 
Naturally, we have the same kind of tradition and the same kind of habits.

I have no white guild, but i'm a big Europe proponent... And I HATE it, if 
people start pretending that ONE country in the EU is dominant, supreme or 
better then the others. It is simply not true.

And Dawkins isn't doing that, but YOU are.
comments.author: Myst Eerie

comments.text:
+Myst Eerie "And in Britain" - It makes perfect sense that he said 
that.Number 1 because he is British,number 2 because he most likely is in 
Britain,number 3 the focus of his work may very well be in Britain.

I am from Portugal. My native idiom is Portuguese and it seems it is you 
who is unaware of the dynamics of global culture.
You see,it's difficult for you Brits (and Americans as well) to see how 
much of your culture is exported sometimes because you're living in it. But 
every movie,every actor,every album,every fast food restaurant,every gadget 
you see in English is exportation of Anglosphere culture. When I say 
supremacy,I mean that the British Empire and it's sons: the 
English-speaking powerhouses have come to dominate the modern world 
culturally and in terms of prosperity and technological advancement.
This is not an opinion and it's *not* a value judgement. It's a factual 
claim that can be attested. When a foreign book is released the first 
priority is to translate it into English otherwise the rest of the world 
won't know about it.
It's not because English is easier,that's very retarded. English is not 
easier than the rest.I can speak German and Dutch so I can tell. It's 
because the British Empire expanded it's influence to global proportions. 
It wasn't a decision by some "big shot". It came through will power and 
military dominance.If things were different it would have been the Chinese 
or the Indians but that's not the case.

Now I've already said why it's hard for Anglophones to see how much 
cultural exportation their countries produce. If you still can't see it, 
maybe you're suffering from colonial/white guilt or something. That's not 
my problem.

even though evolution is commonly called the "Theory of Evolution", it's 
not a theory in the way he commonly identify a hypothesis or a guess, even 
an educated one. A theory refers to a scientific hypothesis that has 
already been proven based on calculations, research and evidence. 
Therefore, it's chance of being true is 99.9%. Some other "theories" would 
be cell theory, quantum theory and atomic theory. These are theories that 
have been well-substantiated and proven with experimentation and 
observation. It's not just an ideology or a "religion" where people say 
that it is true and all the "followers" come gathering around and agreeing 
without any proof (which is what many religions do).

comments.text:
I think the biggest problem with the compatibility of science and religion 
is that integration of science into religion weakens religion. For example 
if you look at most of the modern religious apologist they present a very 
nuanced and complex view of God. However that view does not look anything 
like traditional religious thinking (in fact it would have been considered 
heresy.) Gods have always operated at the perimeter of ignorance. Gods used 
to be the reason for droughts and earthquakes. Now we know they're caused 
by weather patterns and tectonic plates respectively. Now that practically 
every one in the 1st world has a camera on them at all times the sighting 
of angels doesn't happen any more.

Religion and science aren't totally incompatible but every discovery of 
science renders supernatural explanations less likely and impotent. God is 
removed from his traditional place as a concerned and active participant in 
the world to the watchmaker of deism. The defining aspects of god become so 
vague it leads to a troubling state of credulity where anything can be 
interpreted as god, it's so vague that it becomes functionally meaningless. 
As example would be in the past it was commonly believed God and heaven 
were located in the clouds. Now those who endeavor to reconcile science 
with religion have relegated god to being a feeling, or existing outside 
our universe and countless other forms of vagary.

comments.text:
Sorry for the late reply, I'll try to reply to your points in the order 
that you stated them in. Firstly, you said there are now living theoretical 
physicists who are Christian. Well, there are some and you can pick and 
choose however much you want, but 96% of all physicists are atheist and 
that's gotta show that physics and religion don't go so well almost all the 
time. Also, I like to think of religion as sexuality. For example, I'm sure 
both of us can agree that heterosexuality and homosexuality are complete 
opposites and contradict each other. A heterosexual man cannot be a 
homosexual man and vice-versa. However, you can be a heterosexual, for 
example, that supports homosexuality. It's the same for science and 
religion. You can be scientists who is religious, but the 2 ideas are still 
contradictory. This is because religion for the most part is belief without 
evidence (the definition of faith). Most religious people believe what they 
believe because a book or some scripture says so. When somebody opposes and 
criticises their religious beliefs, they hide behind their right to hold a 
belief. On the other hand, science does not take its knowledge from ancient 
books or scriptures. It aims to find out the truth about the universe. It 
does not accept the most probable answer, only the correct answer. For 
example, the fact that life is so complex yet beautiful most probably means 
that it was made by a creator. However, for science, just because it's the 
most probable answer doesn't mean it is the answer. Science tries to find 
exactly what causes life and perhaps life's purpose. When somebody 
criticises scientific knowledge and beliefs, scientists are open to it and 
even encourage criticism so that they can improve on their research and 
findings.

You said god's laws/ commandments apply to the behaviour of people, and not 
natural laws. Well, that's not what the Bible and many Christians would 
think. The Bible claims to understand and explain natural things, such as 
that god created Earth, the Universe and life. Many such claims about the 
natural world have now been refuted by science. Also, the Bible says no one 
should work on the Sabbath. Anyone who does should be stoned to death. If 
you really want to follow the Bible as it is, see whether you can follow 
that "Law" as stated in the Bible. In fact, it's not god or anything divine 
that gives us our morality and understanding. It's really just our brain. 

Let me explain a scenario to you. Let's say that recently one of your loved 
ones passed away, and you are immensely depressed and don't feel the will 
to do anything anymore. When you go to a psychiatrist, the psychiatrist 
says "The solution is simple. Just believe that the person didn't die, and 
you won't be sad that he died anymore." There's an obvious problem with 
this solution. The thing is, even though believing that the person didn't 
die will restore your psychological health, you know that he did die. So, 
even though it's useful to believe that he didn't die, it's simply 
impossible to believe such a thing because you know the truth. Similarly, 
while it may be useful to believe that a god exists, what matters most is 
the truth, and the truth is that no god exists. You cannot hold a belief 
based on its utility. Beliefs are based on evidence. I believe a table is 
brown because I see it to be brown, and so do others. It's the same thing 
for a god.

comments.text:
Science cannot reject the idea of a creator theoretically. Science can't 
disprove a creator's existence. However, there are other theories in 
science such as the theory of evolution, the Big Bang theory, the black 
hole theories, etc that indirectly reject the existence of a creator, 
because these theories in a way replace the need for a creator. Think of it 
like this: There's a small box in front of you, and you don't know what's 
inside. It could be anything . One day, you open up the box and see that x 
is actually inside, and you know that x cannot coexist with any other thing 
inside the box (in the same way that the scientific theories cannot coexist 
with the idea of a creator). Thus, although you cannot directly disprove 
that something else exists in the box, because x exists in the box, it's 
highly unlikely that anything else can. It's this way that scientific 
theories "overthrow" the idea of a creator.

*Der 20. Mai ist der 140. Tag des gregorianischen Kalenders* (der 141. in 
Schaltjahren), somit verbleiben noch 225 Tage bis zum Jahresende. Dieser 
Tag ist der letzte im Tierkreiszeichen Stier, bevor die Zeit im Zeichen 
Zwillinge beginnt.
Noch 22 Wochen und 4 Tage zur guten alten Zeitrechnung.

*Deutscher Venentag*
*Kamerun: Nationalfeiertag*
*Welt-Ernte-Erdbeeren-Tag*
*Welt-Sei-ein-Millionär-Tag*

Video-Wochenmotto: Symphony Of Science (Woche 2)

Video des Tages:
"A Wave of Reason" is the seventh installment in the Symphony of Science 
music video series. It is intended to promote scientific reasoning and 
skepticism in the face of growing amounts of pseudoscientific pursuits, 
such as Astrology and Homeopathy, and also to promote the scientific 
worldview as equally enlightening as religion. It features Carl Sagan, 
Bertrand Russell, Sam Harris, Michael Shermer, Lawrence Krauss, Carolyn 
Porco, Richard Dawkins, Richard Feynman, Phil Plait, and James Randi. 

Ereignisse:
526: Einem Erdbeben in Antiochia und Syrien fallen laut Angaben des 
Historikers Johannes Malalas bis zu 250.000 Menschen zum Opfer.
1498: Der portugiesische Entdecker Vasco da Gama erreicht Indien und landet 
in Calicut. Die Suche nach dem Seeweg nach Indien ist für Portugal damit 
mit Erfolg abgeschlossen.
1503: Der portugiesische Seefahrer Afonso de Albuquerque entdeckt im 
Südatlantik eine in Vergessenheit geratene Insel wieder, der er nun den 
Namen Assunção gibt, weil sie am Tag Christi Himmelfahrt gesichtet worden 
ist. Unter dem ins Englische übersetzten Namen Ascension ist sie bekannt.
1515: Erstmals seit dem 3. Jahrhundert setzt in Lissabon ein Nashorn seinen 
Fuß auf europäischen Boden. Albrecht Dürer setzt dem Tier im gleichen Jahr 
mit seinem Holzschnitt Rhinocerus ein Denkmal.
1570: Der flämische Geograph Abraham Ortelius veröffentlicht in Antwerpen 
das Theatrum Orbis Terrarum, den ersten modernen Atlas.
1873: Der Stoffhändler Levi Strauss und der Schneider Jacob Davis lassen 
gemeinsam genietete Hosen aus Denim-Stoff patentieren, die sogenannten 
Jeans.
1927: Charles Lindbergh startet mit seinem Flugzeug Spirit of St. Louis vom 
Roosevelt-Flugplatz in New York zur ersten Alleinüberquerung des Atlantiks.
1932: Amelia Earhart startet von Neufundland aus als erste Frau zu einer 
Alleinüberquerung des Atlantiks mit einem Flugzeug.
1983: Luc Montagnier und Françoise Barré-Sinoussi vom Institut Pasteur in 
Paris veröffentlichen erstmals eine Beschreibung des HI-Virus, des 
Auslösers der Immunschwächekrankheit AIDS. In derselben Ausgabe des 
Journals Science veröffentlicht der US-Amerikaner Robert Gallo, der Leiter 
des Tumorvirus-Labors am National Institutes of Health (NIH), ebenfalls die 
Entdeckung eines Virus, das seiner Meinung nach AIDS auslösen könnte. Er 
beschreibt in dieser Veröffentlichung jedoch die Isolierung von Humanen 
T-Zell-Leukämie-Viren Typ I (HTLV-1).

comments.text:
It's true that you can get the same type of spiritual fulfillment with 
science as some get from religion... infact even more since you can be 
confident that these stories about the universe that science tells are 
publically verifiable through experiments that even you can do... rather 
than stories from a old book that aren't testable in any way, and the book 
often contains stuff like seven headed dragons and such... It feels good to 
have confidence in something that you yourself can test instead of just 
having to rely on someone else's words.


We also don't have to be "anti-religion" so strongly like some atheists 
are... We just have to become "scientists" again.. We don't need a degree 
to be a scientist.. as Carl Sagan once put, we are all natural born 
scientists! As babies we test and try things all the time.. That is how we 
learn. We are taught religion.. so, we all just need to remember our 
earlier methods =)﻿
